nexttext:
\end{remark}

\begin{corollary}\label{regularity-edge-leaf}
Let $G$ be a simple finite graph on $[n]$ with a free vertex,
say $n,$ and $G' = G \cup \{(n,n+1)\}$. Let $S =
K[x_1,\ldots,x_n,y_1,\ldots,y_n]$ and $S'=S[x_{n+1},y_{n+1}]$.  Then
$\beta_{i,i+j}(S'/J_{G'}) = \beta_{i,i+j}(S/J_G) +
\beta_{i-1,i+j-2}(S/J_G)$. In particular,
${\operatorname{reg}}(S'/J_{G'}) = {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G)+1$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof} Since $n$ is a free vertex in $G$, by Lemma 21 of \cite{zz13}, $x_ny_{n+1}-x_{n+1}y_n$ is a regular
element on $S'/J_G$. Note that ${\operatorname{Tor}}_i^S(K,S/J_G) \cong
{\operatorname{Tor}}_i^{S'}(K,S'/J_G)$. Hence by Remark \ref{bettitable}, we get
$\beta_{i,i+j}(S'/J_{G'}) = \beta_{i,i+j}(S/J_G) +
\beta_{i-1,i+j-2}(S/J_G)$. Therefore it follows directly from the
betti table that ${\operatorname{reg}}(S'/J_{G'}) = {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G)+1$.
\end{proof}

Now we obtain a lower bound on the regularity of the binomial edge
ideals of trees in terms of the number of internal vertices.
Given a tree $T$, it is easy to see that one can construct $T$ from
the trivial graph by adding vertices $v_i$ to $T_{i-1}$ at step $i$ to
get  $T_i$   so that $v_i$ is a leaf in in the tree $T_i$. Such an
ordering of vertices is called a {\em leaf ordering}.  

\begin{theorem}\label{tree-regularity}
If $G$ is a tree with $m$ internal vertices, then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \geq
m+1$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof} Let $v_1, \ldots, v_r$ be a leaf ordering of the
vertices of $G$, and let $G_i$ be the subgraph of $G$  induced by $v_1,
\ldots, v_i$. Let $m_i$ denote the number of internal vertices of
$G_i$. We argue by induction on $i$. If $i = 2$, then $G_2$
is an edge and ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_2}) = 1$. Therefore, the result holds.
Assume the result for $G_i$. Then $G_{i+1}$ is obtained by adding a
leaf $v_{i+1}$ to some vertex $v$ of $G_i$. If $v$ is a leaf in
$G_i$, then $v$ is a free vertex in $G_i$, and hence by Corollary
\ref{regularity-edge-leaf},  ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_{i+1}})= {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_i})+1$.
Further, $v$ becomes a new internal vertex in $G_i$, i.e.,
$m_{i+1}=m_i +1$, and therefore the result holds.
If $v$ is an internal vertex in $G_i$, then $m_{i+1}=m_i$ and since
$G_i$ is an induced subgraph of $G_{i+1}$,  ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_{i+1}}) \ge
{\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_i}) \geq m_i + 1 = m_{i+1}+1$ as required.
\end{proof}









Now we prove an upper bound for the regularity of the binomial edge
ideals of ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graphs.
\begin{theorem}\label{thm:pathclique}
Let $G$ be a ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graph having a path $P$ of length $\ell$ on
vertices $\{v_0,\ldots,v_{\ell}\}$ and cliques $C_1, \ldots, C_r$
attached to $P$.  Then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq \ell+r$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Let $G$ be a graph as given in the statement of the theorem. We prove
the assertion by induction on $\ell+r$, i.e., the number of maximal
cliques in $G$. If $r = 0$, then $G$ is a path and
hence the result holds. Let $p = \min\{j \mid v_j \notin C_i 
\mbox{ for all } i\}$. If $p \leq \ell-2,$ then by removing
$v_{p+2},\ldots,v_\ell$, the resulting graph $G'$ satisfies the
property ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G)= {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'})+ \ell - p -1$, by repeated
application of Corollary~\ref{regularity-edge-leaf}. Therefore, 
we may assume that $p \geq \ell-1$. Let $F_1, \ldots, F_m$ be a
leaf-ordering of the maximal cliques in $G$ such that $F_m$ is either
the edge $(v_{\ell-1},v_\ell)$ or $F_m = C_i$ for some $i$ and $v_\ell
\in C_i$.
Let $F_{i_1}, \ldots, F_{i_q}$ be such that $F_{i_j}
\cap F_m = \{v_k\},$ where $k \in \{\ell-1,\ell\}$ and $F_m \cap P =
\{v_k\}$. Let $G'$ be the graph
obtained by inserting a clique on the vertices $F_m \cup F_{i_1}
\cup \cdots \cup F_{i_q}$ and $G''$ be the graph induced by $[n]
\setminus \{v\}$. Then as in the proof of \cite[Theorem 1.1]{ehh11},
we have the exact sequence:
\begin{eqnarray}\label{exactseq}
0 \longrightarrow \frac{S}{{\operatorname{in}}_<(J_G)} \longrightarrow \frac{S}{{\operatorname{in}}_<(J_{G'})} \oplus
\frac{S}{(x_i,y_i)+{\operatorname{in}}_<(J_{G''})} \longrightarrow
\frac{S}{(x_i,y_i)+{\operatorname{in}}_<(J_{G'})} \longrightarrow 0.
\end{eqnarray}
Note that $G'$ is a ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graph with number of 
maximal cliques $\ell+r-q$, $q \geq 1$. Therefore, by
induction, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'}) \leq \ell + r - q \leq \ell+r-1$. It can
also be seen that $G''$ has $q+2$ connected
components, namely $F'_{i_1}, \ldots, F'_{i_q}, F'_m, G_1''$, where
$F_j'$ is either an isolated vertex or $C_{j}\setminus\{v_k\}$ for
some $j$ and $G_1'' = G
\setminus (F_{i_1}\cup \cdots \cup F_{i_q} \cup F_m).$ Therefore
${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) = \sum_{j=1}^q {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{F'_{i_j}}) + {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{F'_m})
+ {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_1''})$. It is easy to see that $G_1''$ is a ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graph
 with a path of length $\ell-1$ and  with either $r-q$ or $r-q-1$ cliques of size
 at least three depending on whether $F_m$ is an edge or not.  By induction hypothesis, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_1''}) \leq
(\ell-1)+r-q$, if $F_m$ is an edge  or ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G_1''}) \leq
(\ell-1)+r-q-1$ otherwise, in which case  ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{F'_m})=0$. Therefore, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) \leq \ell+r.$ Now it
follows from the short exact sequence (\ref{exactseq}) that ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G)
\leq {\operatorname{reg}}(S/{\operatorname{in}}_<(J_G)) \leq \ell+r$.
\end{proof}

\begin{corollary}
If $G$ is a ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graph with a path $P$ of length $\ell,$ $r$
maximal cliques of size at least $3$ and $t$ limbs
attached to $P$, then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq \ell+r+t$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
We prove by induction on $t$.
If $t=0$, then the result follows from Theorem \ref{thm:pathclique}.
Let $t \geq 1$. Let $v$ be a leaf on a limb and $N(v) = \{u\}$. Let
$G'$ be the graph obtained by adding a clique on the vertices on $N(u)
\cup \{u\}$ and $G''$ be the graph induced on $[n] \setminus \{u\}$.
Note that $G'$ has $r+1$ maximal cliques of size at least three and
$t-1$ limbs. By induction, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'}) \leq \ell+(r+1)+(t-1) =
\ell+r+t$. Moreover, $G''$ has $r$ maximal cliques of size at least
three and $t-1$ limbs. Therefore, by induction ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) \leq
\ell+r+t-1$. By the exact sequence (\ref{exactseq}), we have
${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq \ell+r+t$.
\end{proof}

\begin{example}
This is an example to show that the bound given in Theorem
\ref{thm:pathclique} is sharp.

Let $G$ be a graph as given here. Then $G$ is a ${\operatorname{clique-path}}$ graph
with path $P$ of length $\ell=2$ and $r = 2$ cliques.
It can be seen that ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) = 4 = \ell+r$.

\vskip 2mm
Now we prove the regularity bound for a subclass of trees, namely the
lobsters.
\begin{theorem}\label{upperbound}
If $G$ is a lobster with spine $P$ of length $\ell$ with $t$ limbs and
$r$ whiskers attached to the spine $P$, then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq
\ell+t+r+2$.
\end{theorem}
\begin{proof}
Let $G$ be a graph with spine $P$ of length $\ell$ with $t$ limbs and
$r$ whiskers attached to the spine $P$. Let $G'$ be the graph obtained
from $G$ by extending each whisker to a limb by adding a new edge to
a new distinct vertex. Then the spine length of $G'$ will be either
$\ell$ or $\ell+1$ or $\ell+2$, depending upon whether there is a
whisker attached to the penultimate vertices of each side of the
spine. Note that $G'$ can have at most two new whiskers. Then we have
the following cases:
\vskip 2mm
\noindent
\textsc{Case I:} Suppose $G'$ has no new whiskers. Then $G'$ is a graph
with no whiskers and $t+r$ limbs. By Theorem
\ref{thm:pathclique}, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'}) \leq \ell+t+r$. Since $G$
is an induced subgraph of $G$, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'})$.

\vskip 2mm
\noindent
\textsc{Case II:} Suppose $G'$ has only one new whisker. Then extend
this whisker to a limb as done above and obtain a new graph $G''$ with
spine length $\ell+1, ~ t+r$ limbs and no whiskers. Then by Theorem
\ref{thm:pathclique}, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) \leq \ell+t+r+1$. Since
$G$ is an induced subgraph of $G''$, we have ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq
{\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''})$.

\vskip 2mm
\noindent
\textsc{Case III:} Suppose $G'$ has two new whiskers. As done earlier,
extend these two whiskers to limbs to obtain $G''$. Then $G''$ has
spine length $\ell+2, ~ t+r$ limbs and no whiskers. Therefore by
Theorem \ref{thm:pathclique}, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) \leq
\ell+t+r+2$. As $G$ is an induced subgraph of $G''$, we have
${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''})$.

\vskip 2mm
\noindent
Hence ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq \ell+t+r+2$.
\end{proof}

\begin{example}
This is an example of a lobster which achieves the upper
bound given in Theorem \ref{upperbound}.

This graph $G$ has many different longest induced paths. Fixing any
one of them, one can see that $G$ has spine length $\ell=4$, $t=4$
limbs and $r=2$ whiskers attached to the spine. A computation on
Macaulay2 shows that the ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) = 12 = \ell+t+r+2$. 

\end{minipage}
\end{minipage}
\end{example}


Below, we obtain a precise expression for the regularity of the
binmoial edge ideal of a subclass of lobsters.
\begin{theorem}\label{purelobster}
If $G$ is a lobster with spine length $\ell$ and
$t$ limbs of the form $K_{1,2}$ attached to the spine, then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) = \ell+t$.
\end{theorem}

\begin{proof}
Let $G$ be a lobster with spine $P$ of length $\ell$ and $t$ 
limbs of the form $K_{1,2}$ attached to the spine $P$. Let $G'$ be the caterpillar graph
obtained by deleting all the leaves of $G$ which are not on the spine
$P$ of $G$. Then ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'}) = \ell$, \cite{cdi14}. Let $m$ be a
leaf of $G$ and $(m,m+1)$ be an edge in $G$. Let $G''$ denote the
graph $G'\cup \{(m,m+1)\}$. Then by Corollary
\ref{regularity-edge-leaf}, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G''}) = \ell+1$. Observe that
$G$ is obtained by iterating the above procedure of attaching a vertex
to a leaf $t$-times. Since a vertex is attached to a leaf, the
regularity increases exactly by one at each step. Therefore,
${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) = \ell+t$.
\end{proof}
\begin{corollary}
Let $G$ be a lobster with spine $P$ of length $\ell$, $t$ limbs and
$r$ whiskers. Then $\ell + t \leq {\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_G) \leq \ell+t+r+2$.
\end{corollary}
\begin{proof}
The upper bound is proved in Theorem \ref{upperbound}. To prove the
lower bound, note that $G$ has a subgraph $G'$ with spine $P$, $t$
pure limbs and without any whiskers as an induced subgraph. By Theorem
\ref{purelobster}, ${\operatorname{reg}}(S/J_{G'}) = \ell+t$ as required.
\end{proof}
